According to the CDC, Candida auris (C. auris) is "an emerging fungus that presents a serious global health threat." Candida auris, often abbreviated as C. auris, is a multidrug-resistant fungus that poses a significant global health threat. First identified in 2009 in Japan, C. auris has since been reported in various countries, causing severe infections, particularly in healthcare settings. What makes C. auris alarming is its resistance to multiple antifungal medications, making it challenging to treat and control. This opportunistic pathogen primarily affects individuals with weakened immune systems, often leading to bloodstream infections, wound infections, and ear infections. Due to its resistance and ability to persist in the environment, C. auris can spread easily in healthcare facilities. Controlling its transmission involves rigorous infection control measures and heightened awareness within healthcare communities. C. auris underscores the importance of global surveillance, rapid detection, and collaborative efforts to address emerging threats in infectious diseases. "People can get C. auris on their skin and other body sites without getting sick or having an infection," the CDC explains. Patient Screening: Consider routine screening for C. auris colonization, especially for patients at higher risk or those with prolonged hospital stays.
